posts.cooked:
Hello,

I have a question relating to PID loops for swerve module angle setting. Our swerve modules can set pretty accurately from say 0 degrees to 90 degrees (maximum angular distance needed to travel) but they are slightly off, especially with setting between smaller angle values like from 5 degrees to 0 degrees. I was thinking of using Ki to remedy this, but from intial tests it is either too slow or too disruptive (low values to high values respectively). Does anyone have any tips? This is a problem for us because the slight angle difference is causing autonomous drift. Thank you!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: we’ve seen that same thing due to friction or stiction: steering the wheel while the tread is fully involved with the carpet takes a fair amount of force.  do you have friction terms in your steering motor feedforward?

We encountered problems using feedforward with position setting. The feeforward would get off by a bit, but we could not use accurate PID to remedy that because increasing it would then make the feedforward overshoot. The wheels are definitely drifting due to the carpet moving them. I’m pretty sure Ks is used to overcome friction by the wheel when it sets position, not to resist friction induced by driving, but I may be wrong.

posts.name: sspoldi
posts.cooked:
We do inner/outer loop control, with a stiff PI inner velocity loop, and an outer prportional position loop. This has the same disturbance rejecton as PID without the unavoidable position overshoot with the integrator operating on position error. Look at any of the closed loop controls on team 230’s software, we use it a lot.

Sorry i don’t have a link, I’m on my phone, but I’ll try to look one up.
If you don’t mind my asking, could you give a simple explanation of inner and outer loop control? I’ve never encountered a more complex feedback control system so I’m curious.

posts.name: sspoldi
posts.cooked:
Try here, this is our prototype swerve setup:

Team 230 swerve base offseason project. Contribute to Gaelhawks-Team-230/FRC-team230-Swerve2022-Prod development by creating an account on GitHub.

link_counts.title: GitHub - Gaelhawks-Team-230/FRC-team230-Swerve2022-Prod: Team 230 swerve base offseason project

posts.name: sspoldi
posts.cooked:
This is our basic control law:

pos_error = pos_cmd - pos vel_cmd = pos err * Kpos vel_err = vel_cmd - vel motor_cmd = Kp * vel_err + Ki * integral(vel_err)

Kp and Ki are just 2/3ds of a pid controller, and K_pos is a proportional controller around the whole thing.

I’m driving the robot to the Waterbury event in like 2 minutes, but I’ll be happy to give you any help you need when i get free.

Cheers, Steve
So I think the idea is that you get a velocity based on the position error, and then you make sure that velocity is correct using proportional and integral control?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
that’s right; you’re essentially calibrating the positional output as an actual velocity setpoint.

100 do something similar to 230, with a few changes:

velocity/acceleration limited (i.e. profiled) positional control

feedforward for static and dynamic friction

no I terms anywhere

outboard velocity control in the motor controller at 1khz

most of our motor controls work this same way, an outboard velocity servo with an optional onboard positional control on top.

posts.name: sspoldi
posts.cooked:
Yes, you have that right. This is actually a very old school approach, used when we had analog tachometers and digital position loops. It’s very flexable, and allows for different velocity and position sensors, which we do a lot.

The integrator is key to good performance,  it creates a fast accurate velocity loop,  works really well.

Can this help with like small angle errors, like 0 degrees to 7 degrees? We’re having trouble with those, as they cause drift in even straight line autos, and if we can fix it and have accurate loops for both that and drive velocity then we don’t have to worry about following complex paths badly.

posts.name: sspoldi
posts.cooked: Very much so. the integrator will drive the steady state velocity error to zero. The faster responding  the system is, the more important the integral feedback is. This is exactly what we do, and perform odometery on the commands to control our autononous. Our velocity control and inner steering loops are virtually the same.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.cooked: So from what I understand, using integral control to control the resulting velocity from the position controller is better than integrating the position error?

posts.name: sspoldi
posts.cooked:
I just happened to have a comparison I did between these two methods: IOL_vs_PID 770×581 22.6 KB In this case I apply a step input to both at t = 0.1 seconds (that’s your command response) and a disturbance at t = 3.0 seconds (robot gets hit, that’s your disturbance response).

IOL_vs_PID 770×581 22.6 KB

IOL_vs_PID 770×581 22.6 KB

I selected PID gains to make the disturbance response identical. Note that the PID response has a single overshoot (this is the integrator operating on position error). You may prefer one over the other, and you can put a filter inline with the input command to make either look like the other.

I’ve attached a txt file that is actually an Octave command file (rename to pid_v_iol.m). Octave is an analysis tool that is practically identical in syntax to Matlab, and is a fantastic utility to use for this type of stuff. It is distributed under the GNU public license, and has binaries for Linux as well as Windows. We have it on most of our team laptops, it’s a lot like Python, but easier in my opinion.

If you look at the file, you’ll see a simple simulation of each method with the same plant to control. You can see how I convert the inner/outer loop parameters to PID gains. I’ve been working on presentation materials to teach this to the team members, I apologize that this isn’t a more complete description.

We do a lot of simulation in this manner, it’s really quick, and doesn’t require anything other than a computer.

I hope this adds more clarity than confusion, please reach out if you need some additional support.

Sicerely, Steve Spoldi, team 230. pid_v_iol.txt (1.9 KB)

posts.name: sspoldi
posts.cooked: I guess I didn’t answer your question. It’s not better, just different. A little overshoot might not be bad for swerve steering.
